The argument is not logically valid because it does not follow a valid logical form. The argument is an example of a fallacy known as "affirming the consequent." This fallacy occurs when the conclusion is a statement that affirms the consequent of the premise, but the argument does not provide any reason to believe that the premise and the conclusion share a common cause or necessary connection.

In this case, the premise is 'If I take medication, I will feel better.' The conclusion is 'If I take medication that expired, I will feel better.' The argument assumes that taking expired medication will have the same effect as taking non-expired medication, but it does not provide any reason to believe that this is the case.

No, the argument is not logically valid.
